SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove insufficient for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If you have extra sheets of paper, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pilot: What 3rd Western Canadian Pioneer Pilot is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so please put a check mark here ( )."

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires conditions
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer schooling
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan, and will be sent to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is desirable to complete a general questionnaire on pioneer life because an individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

In absence of space, if there is not sufficient space to answer all the questions, they should be written on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: That's All," Western Canadian Pioneer Bat is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name ...........................................
2. Your address ..............................................
3. Date .......................................................
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
7. First in June, 1903.
8. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible.
9. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under 18 years of age.)
10. Twenty-three.
11. What were your reasons for coming West?
12. There were too many people in our family and we only had one acre of land.
13. Railroad or government influence.
14. Mostly through newspapers, literature.

A. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Our coming was a family arrangement. All were agreed on the advisability or seeking more and better opportunities.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Myself and brother H.W. Miller came first in 1903 to spy out the land end file on Homesteads.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Came by Railway.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way etc.)

There were no particular incidents on this trip. We came with our effects and family in 1904. We landed in Regina at the time of the Imudson flood. We established a store for three weeks. We decided to take our horses and cattle overland. We were bogged down in sloughs when there was a half inch of water. We had to go in and release them. A guide at Imudson to pilot us over. The town was wetter than a party of dogs who swam along behind the title and wagon box. We hired a boat. The party who would not pay the $5.00 asked by the owner I turned up. In the deep snow and litter we saw them get the box and die four days after we arrived.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We camped in tents on our land until we erected buildings.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Three and one half miles east of Eldworth

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Lived in Vancouver for one year 1914 November to 1915 November

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Farming and buying live stock
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Our counseling was a family arrangement. All were agreed on the advisability of seeking more and better opportunities.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Myself and brother H.W. Miller came first in 1903 to spy out the land and fill on homesteads.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Came by Railways.

14. Most incidents of the journey? Yes; do you remember? (People you met on the way etc.) There were no particular incidents on this trip. We came with our effects and family in 1904. We landed in Regina at the time of the Inundation. The horses fell ill and go on land we were obliged there for three weeks. We decided to take a ride at Inundation to pilot us over. We were told we had to go in and release them when there was half an hour to go. We did so and they were released. We had a dog who was along behind the string and could not get away. We hired another party who would not pay the $3.00 asked by the owner. This party helped us help a deep gully and their wagon flopped away with the men ashore. One of the men went short and later we saw them get the box journey. One of our horses rolled the box and continue their journey. One of our horses died four days after.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We camped in tents on our land until we erected buildings.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Three and one half miles east of Gladworth.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. I lived in Vancouver for one year 1914-1915 November.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How about you now?
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Two or three times a year. We came as a whole family so had only cousins with whom to correspond.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married November first, 1914 to Isabelle Anne Simpson at Windypeg, Manitoba.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, who?

Yes there were at least three families settled here.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

We all settled in the one place.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Getting lost in blizzards. The large herds of cattle and the prevalence of both coyotes and foxes.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting relatives, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Very little. An occasional business trip to "cities" or Saskatoon, always by train.
13. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Two or three times a year. We came as a whole family so had only cousins with whom to correspond.

20. If you are married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married November first, 1914 to Isabella Anne Simpson at Windypog.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

Yes there were at least three families settling here.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came first:

Tell when they came and where they settled.

We all settled in the one place.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Settling lost in blizzards. The large herds of cattle and the prevalence of both coyotes and foxes.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

Very little. An occasional business trip to "city" or Saskatoon always by train.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
In 1911. Owned by the late Senator Johnston.

26. If you owned a car before 1911, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade abroad? (Include any changes due to new terms, etc.)

Yes traded here always, for everything that we could purchase

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
Our father did all the shopping as we were too busy on the land.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
I would say around 1925.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogs?
What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

Here bought to any extent from Mail Order houses. Always found it more profitable to buy from local stores. The mail order houses were our neighbors and friends, easy to do business in times of need, and helping to build up the community.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
In 1912. A local Co., connecting up with the Govt. Telephone system for long distance.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of buying land yourself? Or did you take up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

We came with the intention of buying, and our field was unsheltered after seeing the land.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   In 1913. Owned by the late Senator Johnstone.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, what did you pay for it?
   Purchased a car in 1913. Manufactured by the Buick Co.

27. What was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Bradford, back three and one half miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (List any changes due to new towns appearing.)
   Yes, traded here always, for everything that we could purchase.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Our father did all the shopping as we were too busy on the land.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   I would say around 1915.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   We bought by mail order except from Mr. Miller. Other houses always found it easier to order from a store.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   In 1913, a local Co., connecting up with the Govt. Telephone system.

33. Then you began to communicate through the first time was it with the idea of talking to someone else?
5.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

An old one, mostly people who were not bone fide farmers, and who proved up on their quarter sections and sold them.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

I know of only one person who moved away during the 1920s.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was President of Agricultural Society, Treasurer of the Patriotic Fund, Town Overseer of the Village for nineteen years, and Chairman of the School Board for nine years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I was the first person to buy land of wheel in two of the R.R. tickets sold here.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, Villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name; (2) date it was given; (3) reason for naming; (4) any other interesting facts.

I only know the origin of one S.D., Silver Lake. It was near a small lake of that name.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? If so, why?

An odd one, mostly people who were not bone fide farmers, and who proved up on their quarter sections and sold them.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Yes quite a number of families. I would say that twenty-five per cent returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

I was President of Agricultural Society, President of the Patriotic Fund Inc., Overseer of the Village for nineteen years and Chairman of the School Board for nine years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I was the first person to buy land of wheat in two of the thirty-eight sections and myself and brother purchased the first R.H. Wilkette sod house.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, Villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first mention; (5) present name; (6) reason for change; (7) give dates of name changes if known.

I only know the origin of one S.D. Silver Lake. It was near a small lake of that name.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old photos, and perhaps minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old newspapers, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I am afraid I have nothing that would be of interest.

40. Would you or the person who owns them either
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

40a. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

James Simpson Miller a Squadron Leader in the Permanent Air Force now located at Claresholm, Alta. He has one son James William.
Hugh McGeary, a Grain Buyer at Kenaston, Sask.
Jean Isboll (now Mrs. W.R. Spronk) whose husband is manager of the Oron Mine at Yellow Knife N.W.T.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The mechanization of the farms. So far as our community life is concerned a change for the worse in the writer's opinion. The advent of the large farm, has been the closing of schools. Life through lack of scholars, and has been a draw back to communal life.

Please give the names and addresses of other persons who could answer this questionnaire.

Alexander Jacob Ault,
George Herbert MacLind Rumball,
Alfred Leslie Rosenquist,
Ludwig Peter Braun.

If anyone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
I am afraid I have nothing that would be of interest.

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the University Office at the University in Saskatoon?

If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

James Shapton Miller & Squadron Leader in the Permanent Air Force now located at Clareholm, Alta., he has one son James William, Hugh McCreary, a Grain Buyer (W.H. Spoonill) whose husband is manager of the Coal Mine at Yellowknife N.W.T.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The mechanization of the farms. So far as our community life is concerned a change for the worse in the writer's opinion. The advent of the large farms, has seen the closing of schools, Life through lack of scholars, and has been a draw back to rural life.

Alfred Harris Rosendal,
Ludwig Peter Braun.
